Award.AwardTitle: Spatially resolved studies of transport and selectivity of chemically reacting flows in topologically distinct microporous frameworks
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Louis Bouchard at the University of California, Los Angeles is studying the interplay between molecular transport and reaction selectivity in reactions catalyzed by metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). MOF's are three-dimensional structures built, in a tinker toy-like manner, from metal atoms and organic molecules and are of interest to the chemical industry due to the fact that their structure can be easily varied. Several MOFs have been developed as catalysts, but very little is known about the behavior of MOFs inside catalytic reactors, which are used in the industry to carry out reactions. Research in catalysis leads to many new everyday products, lower production costs and increased accessibility worldwide, all of which are desirable outcomes to society. Better and more efficient catalysis, along with the optimization methods will ultimately lead to a cleaner environment, lower production costs and increased accessibility to the consumer. The project is also integrating research, training and education. Graduate and undergraduate students participating in the research project are learning important research and communication skills, and Professor Bouchard is partnering with a local high school to host these students for research experiences in the laboratory.

Professor Bouchard is investigating catalytic reactions from a unique angle: by mapping flow and transport processes occurring inside live reactors and correlating them with the outcomes of the reaction. Thermodynamic fluxes yield an understanding of transport processes in microporous materials, in relation to the catalytic outcome, enabling optimization of reaction parameters and catalyst. Two kinds of reactions are being studied: epoxidations and oligomerizations. Epoxidations are important to the chemical industry, in which epoxides are used as starting materials for the synthesis of polycarbonates. Oligomerizations are important to the petroleum industry, and an important challenge is to maximize selectivity with respect to selected product(s) of the reaction. Professor Bouchard's group found evidence that transport and topology of the framework strongly influence the outcome of such reactions, the details of which are still unclear. A fundamental understanding of the reaction in live reaction settings is therefore needed. In this project microporous catalytic frameworks are being optimized as function of framework topology, size and active centers, with the goal of identifying industrially viable MOF catalysts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this proposal was the study of interplay between transport and selectivity in reactions catalyzed by microporous frameworks. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are of potential interest to the chemical industry due to the record high specific surface and tunability of the framework. Several MOFs have been developed for catalysis purposes, but very little is known about the behavior of MOFs in reactors. Our group has found strong evidence that transport and topology of the framework strongly influence the outcome of such reactions, the details of which are unclear. A fundamental understanding of the reaction in live reaction settings is therefore, absolutely needed. We proposed a multi-pronged line of attack to the optimization of microporous catalytic frameworks and the identification of industrially viable MOF catalysts by controlling the framework topology, size and active centers. Knowledge of gradients involved in transport and chemical processes on reactor scale is of paramount importance for understanding and optimizing such processes. Herein, we proposed to map thermodynamic fluxes inside a live reactor and correlate them with reaction outcome (yield, selectivity). Flux maps will be obtained by computing gradients of thermodynamic intensive properties, such as pressure, temperature and chemical potential. This approach will allow us to gain the best microscopic understanding of transport in microporous materials to exploit it to the maximum potential. Two kinds of reactions were studied.  Aim 1: investigate the epoxidation of long chain alkenes using topologically different porphyrin-based MOFs.  Aim 2: investigate the effect of topology on the oligomerization of gaseous alkenes.

 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

This project aims to accelerate the paradigm shift away from the conventional catalysts and extreme reaction conditions that are commonly used in industry by incorporating catalytic function into a microporous framework that is optimized for selectivity with respect to transport, metalation and topology. MOFs can incorporate multiple functionalities into the same vehicle, and combined with the record high surface areas, provide the ability to pack this functionality at high density. This paradigm shift could be used, for example, in the design of smaller catalytic reactors that operate under milder conditions and therefore improve selectivity, save energy, and chemicals. Demonstrations of this concept with a variety of catalysis and reactions will be undertaken to explore the value of such an approach. While the gas adsorption and retention properties of microporous frameworks have been the subject of extensive studies, the relationship between transport fluxes and selectivity in the highly confined microporous geometries of MOFs is poorly understood. This endeavor will provide a better understanding of this relationship.

 

BROADER IMPACTS

Research in catalysis leads to many new consumer products, lower production costs and increased accessibility worldwide, all of which are desirable outcomes to society. The proposal uses cutting edge techniques for imaging chemical reactions. The field of heterogeneous catalysis could benefit from techniques developed during this project, as they are of a fairly general or adaptable nature. Student exposed to this project would learn about thermodynamics, from a non-equilibrium standpoint, which is outside the standard chemistry curriculum of most universities. Knowledge produced by prior NSF support has been used to improve undergraduate lab experiments at UCLA. Outreach: Several students that worked on this project have been females or from underrepresented minorities, which were recruited through the UCLA CARE program. The PI is involved in extracurricular teaching activities that benefit local (West LA-area) public schools at the high-school level, where primarily minority students are enrolled.

 

We have successfully synthesized all MOFs for all reactions, including novel MOFs.  Epoxidation reactions were carried out and MOF topology was compared.   For oligomerization reactions, MOF topology effects could not be assessed because reaction yield was too low, and increasing temperature caused some damage to the MOFs.   Transport phenomena could be studied in the gas phase.  We have laid the foundation for the development of a new method for probing non-Markovian diffusion effects in porous media.   We have also developed novel catalysts that yield highly polarized molecules; this could be used to increase sensitivity to detection of reactions in real-time.  Several students have been trained during this project.
